text: Hi everyone! Any suggestions on how to streamline bulk video creation for social media posts? I'd love to recycle my company's blog posts into short videos and usually work with Canva - which is super handy for images, but somehow still limited in stock video footage it provides. Free options are especially welcomed)

elements.text: Hi everyone! Any suggestions on how to streamline bulk video creation for social media posts? I'd love to recycle my company's blog posts into short videos and usually work with Canva - which is super handy for images, but somehow still limited in stock video footage it provides. Free options are especially welcomed)

text: If you’re looking for free stock video footage, <https://www.pexels.com/videos/|Pexels> is like the unsplash for video.

attachments.title: Free stock videos · Pexels Videos
attachments.text: Pexels Videos makes it easy to find free stock footage for your website, promo video or anything else. All videos are free for personal and commercial use.

Hi <@U01CS0V4HFG>, I tried a few tools, and for me, the best option is PlayPlay. You can see <https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6704678833599074304|an example of video we made here>.

However, if your budget is limited, Lumen5 and Headliner are also very good options!

text: * <@UUKNSLX9P>

Hi content folks! Does anyone have a good structure/template for their editorial meetings? I run a monthly editorial meeting, which is a new muscle for us. I'm having difficulty getting people across PMM/lead gen/etc to understand that we should all be working on initiatives _together_ to push content forward and get use out of it.

elements.text: Hi content folks! Does anyone have a good structure/template for their editorial meetings? I run a monthly editorial meeting, which is a new muscle for us. I'm having difficulty getting people across PMM/lead gen/etc to understand that we should all be working on initiatives
together
to push content forward and get use out of it.

text: FWW, if I were going to preside over something like that, I'd probably have a kanban/Trello board to model the workflow.  The structure I'd then use would be to touch on each card in flight, ala Scrum standup.  At the very least, that surfaces anything that might stall in production with no responsible party

elements.text: FWW, if I were going to preside over something like that, I'd probably have a kanban/Trello board to model the workflow.  The structure I'd then use would be to touch on each card in flight, ala Scrum standup.  At the very least, that surfaces anything that might stall in production with no responsible party

text: Definitely checking out pexels, thanks for the rec <@UUVC9HJTE>

elements.text: Definitely checking out pexels, thanks for the rec

text: We also use a kanban like Trello board with a content pipeline, from current week (with new ideas), commited articles — things that we’re sure about developing, but haven’t started yet, work in progress — with articles in various phases of development and published. We use labels for publishing channels, collaborators and so on. It’s still a developing process in our case as well and has shifted from idea generating/curating to editorial project management. Hope this helps.

elements.text: We also use a kanban like Trello board with a content pipeline, from current week (with new ideas), commited articles — things that we’re sure about developing, but haven’t started yet, work in progress — with articles in various phases of development and published. We use labels for publishing channels, collaborators and so on. It’s still a developing process in our case as well and has shifted from idea generating/curating to editorial project management. Hope this helps.

text:
Hi <@UPL0XUAG3>! My team (content) hosts a monthly meeting where we invite all those stakeholders. It’s 60 minutes and the rough agenda is broken into two 30-minute sections.

*First half:*
• Introduce the meeting and agenda
• Recap: Organic and paid social performance highlights
• What’s ahead: PMK, Customer Marketing, Demand Gen and any other non-content-focused teams give 2-3 bullet points of what they are focusing on or working on now that content creators should know about. (Opportunities to collab or focus, etc)
• Review content calendar for the upcoming month, discuss any questions, builds or concerns
• (We’ve been doing this for awhile so the above all goes quickly)
*Second half: Brainstorm or discussion*
• This changes every month depending on where we’re focused as a marketing team. Past examples include brainstorming ideas related to an upcoming campaign, different content formats we want to try, article ideas re: a specific major topic, etc. That way we have all of these voices involved, and the brainstorm topic isn’t only decided by content--the person who plans this meeting will go around to other teams to see if they have a brainstorm idea they want input on. If we don’t have anything, we end the meeting at 30.

First half:
Introduce the meeting and agenda
Recap: Organic and paid social performance highlights

What’s ahead: PMK, Customer Marketing, Demand Gen and any other non-content-focused teams give 2-3 bullet points of what they are focusing on or working on now that content creators should know about. (Opportunities to collab or focus, etc)
Review content calendar for the upcoming month, discuss any questions, builds or concerns
(We’ve been doing this for awhile so the above all goes quickly)
Second half: Brainstorm or discussion

This changes every month depending on where we’re focused as a marketing team. Past examples include brainstorming ideas related to an upcoming campaign, different content formats we want to try, article ideas re: a specific major topic, etc. That way we have all of these voices involved, and the brainstorm topic isn’t only decided by content--the person who plans this meeting will go around to other teams to see if they have a brainstorm idea they want input on. If we don’t have anything, we end the meeting at 30.

text: Agree with <@URB31QKM4> here, I find the most successful meetings w/ non-content folks revolve around "what we did" (just published content, plus to-date metrics) and "what we're doing" (scheduled, upcoming content for next 30 to 60 days)

elements.text: Agree with

here, I find the most successful meetings w/ non-content folks revolve around "what we did" (just published content, plus to-date metrics) and "what we're doing" (scheduled, upcoming content for next 30 to 60 days)

text:
Freelancers of CMCG! Looking at the process of expanding my freelance bench for next year and have a burning question.

What assets help you get onboarded to a company's tone/messaging/branding quickly and competently? Style guide, messaging house? Best-of example content?

elements.text:
Freelancers of CMCG! Looking at the process of expanding my freelance bench for next year and have a burning question.

What assets help you get onboarded to a company's tone/messaging/branding quickly and competently? Style guide, messaging house? Best-of example content?

text: Editorial/brand style guides, any messaging frameworks you have, and any sales playbooks. If there will be email-related content, examples of emails that have performed well and even those that haven't.

elements.text: Editorial/brand style guides, any messaging frameworks you have, and any sales playbooks. If there will be email-related content, examples of emails that have performed well and even those that haven't.

text: Yes to style guides - with clear examples of good and bad content and the style you like from articles/white papers/web copy etc. Also any customer personas/an overview of customer data you can share.

elements.text: Yes to style guides - with clear examples of good and bad content and the style you like from articles/white papers/web copy etc. Also any customer personas/an overview of customer data you can share.

text: Brief for the first piece helps too so I can understand what goals your team has with content and how the piece fits into the overall strategy.

elements.text: Brief for the first piece helps too so I can understand what goals your team has with content and how the piece fits into the overall strategy.

text: +1 for customer persona / who they sell to and how they sell to them ...and what a customer or lead is worth to them

elements.text: +1 for customer persona / who they sell to and how they sell to them ...and what a customer or lead is worth to them

text: I also agree with having a brief for each project. A brief for each blog post, for example. Helps writers hit the ground running and requires few (if any revisions).

elements.text: I also agree with having a brief for each project. A brief for each blog post, for example. Helps writers hit the ground running and requires few (if any revisions).

text: The person who organizes also sends out prep work in advance--it’s basically a templatized email that always says the same things (e.g. “Bob, bring 2-3 bullet points about what your team is doing”) but that is a helpful reminder so everyone comes prepared!

elements.text: The person who organizes also sends out prep work in advance--it’s basically a templatized email that always says the same things (e.g. “Bob, bring 2-3 bullet points about what your team is doing”) but that is a helpful reminder so everyone comes prepared!
